context_meta.title: U.S., Israel quit U.N. heritage agency citing bias
context_meta.summary: By John Irish PARIS (Reuters) - The United States and Israel announced on Thursday they were quitting the U.N.'s cultural agency UNESCO, after Washington accused it of anti-Israeli bias. UNESCO is best known for designating World Heritage Sites such as the ancient city of Palmyra in Syria and the Grand Canyon National Park.

The fires, which began on Sunday, have swept through California's wine country, leaving thousands of people homeless and burning over 190,000 acres (76,000 hectares) of land. Gusty winds on Thursday were hampering the efforts of the 8,000 firefighters battling 20 blazes, and weather conditions were not forecast to improve.

text: I have been a supporter of Turkey and the the Turkish people for a long time; but, from my point of view which is admittedly that of an outsider and informed only by the media as well, Mr. Erdogan's behavior and attitudes are very hard to understand. From the point of view of strengthening Western-Turkish understanding and cooperation, he seems to be alienating everyone who would like to be his and the Turkish peoples' friend. From the point of view of advancing Turkey's status as an ally to the West and a leader in the Islamic world, he seems to be isolating his country and burning bridges instead of building them. Instead of creating an "enemy mentality" with the Kurds, wouldn't it be more productive to aid them in the establishment of their own state, helping to create at the same time a new Turkish ally. From the point of view of enhancing Turkey's social environment, he seems to be a self-serving and self-defeating reactionary. From the point of view of advancing Turkey's economic strength, his policies seem so far to be backfiring. Clearly, I do not understand all his motivations and could be completely wrong. Time will tell. Hopefully, he will be able to resolve all the conflicts he seems to have helped to create in such a way that all parties will come back together as friends and allies, with mutual respect and cooperation. It is too easy to quickly and reflexively condemn a leader in his position with his geopolitical problems to face: he loves Turkey and the Turkish people, that much is clear. Hopefully, he will have opportunities to prove this in future.

In the years since, America's friends and foes have shifted, however, and its leading rival, Russia, stepped in to help Syrian President Bashar al-Assad quell a nationwide rebellion and reclaim the lion's share of his country.

context_meta.title: U.S. still seeking explanation for arrest of staff in Turkey: ambassador
context_meta.summary: By Tulay Karadeniz and Gulsen Solaker ANKARA (Reuters) - The United States is still seeking an explanation from Ankara for the detention of staff at U.S. missions in Turkey which led Washington to stop issuing visas and triggered a diplomatic crisis, the U.S. ambassador said on Wednesday. Ambassador John Bass said the decision to suspend granting visas was not taken lightly, but the detentions indicated a breakdown in communication between the two NATO allies, whose relations have come under increasing strain. "Unfortunately... the U.S. government still has not received any official communications from the Turkish government about the reasons why our local employees have been detained or arrested," he told reporters at the U.S. embassy in Ankara.
